ðŸŒŸ Introduction

In mathematics, we often deal with numbers greater than zero, like 1, 2, 3, etc., which are called natural numbers. However, in real life, we also encounter numbers that are less than zero. For example:

  • The temperature in some places can be -5Â°C.
  • In a game, if you lose 10 points, your score may become negative.
  • When withdrawing money from a bank, your account balance might drop below zero, showing negative balance.

To handle such situations, we use integers. Integers include both positive numbers, negative numbers, and zero.

subtopics.title: Definition of Integers
subtopics.content:
1. Definition of Integers

Integers are the set of whole numbers and their negatives.

Written as:

Integers = {..., âˆ’4, âˆ’3, âˆ’2, âˆ’1, 0, 1, 2, 3, 4, ...}

Zero (0) is neither positive nor negative.

subtopics.title: Number Line Representation
subtopics.content:
2. Number Line Representation

  • Integers can be shown on a number line.
  • To the right of 0 â†’ positive integers.
  • To the left of 0 â†’ negative integers.
  • The further right a number is, the greater it is.

Example: On the number line, +3 > -2 because +3 lies to the right of -2.

subtopics.title: Comparing Integers
subtopics.content:
3. Comparing Integers

  • Positive numbers are always greater than negative numbers.
  • Among positive integers, the larger value is greater (e.g., 7 > 3).
  • Among negative integers, the one with a smaller absolute value is greater (e.g., -2 > -5).

subtopics.title: Operations with Integers - Addition and Subtraction
subtopics.content:
4. Operations with Integers

(a) Addition

  • If both integers have the same sign, add their absolute values and keep the sign.
  • If they have different signs, subtract smaller absolute value from larger absolute value, and keep the sign of the larger.

Examples:

  • (+7) + (+3) = +10
  • (-8) + (-4) = -12
  • (+9) + (-5) = +4

(b) Subtraction

  • To subtract, change the sign of the second number and then add.

Examples:

  • (+7) â€“ (+3) = (+7) + (-3) = +4
  • (-5) â€“ (+4) = (-5) + (-4) = -9
  • (-6) â€“ (-2) = (-6) + (+2) = -4

subtopics.title: Absolute Value
subtopics.content:
5. Absolute Value

The absolute value of an integer is its distance from zero on the number line, always positive.

Example: |+5| = 5, |â€“7| = 7
